content: today I bring you a quick and easy new
clip-on feature for your modular tiles the method is simple and fun to execute
requiring cheap and readily available materials and I think that these
stained-glass windows will make a valuable addition to your collection
forever and okay bottom line up front we're gonna start with the glass itself
then we'll come back and talk about the clip-on
this is packaging plastic common in most anything that you can buy just cut a
piece out that's the size of the window you want plus a few millimeters extra
around the perimeter with a black sharpie draw out the design that you
want I'm gonna do a symbol of paler and use Google image search to get some
inspiration for all the little patterns and stuff and flip it over and retrace
everything this will really help solidify the color then use colored
sharpies and just color in between the lines again do this on both sides it's
really that simple I tried multiple Sun catcher paints and frosted glass paints
and none of them gave me the effect I wanted they tended to cloud up the
plastic sharpies tint it properly the way that I wanted so for the clip-on we
make them the same way that we always do a quarter inch of material in the middle
double corrugated cardboard works good for that and then chipboard on two sides
if you're new the channel here's a card with a playlist of clip-on features I've
done in the past so you can make this however you want
I cut out a two by five inch rectangle cut the top of it to a point and then
measure out this sort of pill shape to be removed
nice fresh blade and a metal ruler to make those cuts through the chipboard so
we'll need two chipboard pieces and one more from double corrugated cardboard
with a half-inch chopped off the bottom remember we use that double corrugated
because it's a quarter inch thick and that's how thick our tile walls are
therefore we know the clip on will fit nice and snug now unlike what we usually
do we have to do some painting in advance
first corrugation cladding on the inside of the window this is just 60 pound
cardstock it's thick paper even printer paper would work that's all hot glue it
on the inside and then hot glue one of the chipboard
frames on one side at this point paint everything up as you normally would to
match your dungeon tiles or however you want I'm doing my usual black base
followed by a sponging of dark grey and then a light gray to install the glass
itself thin Mead white glue around the perimeter and set it and then I'm using
hot glue here to attach the other chipboard side and complete the sandwich
this is why we painted in advance you wouldn't be able to get into those those
inner ledges with the sponge you risk getting it out in the window it's just
easier to do it in advance get a nice clean result and finally with hot glue
corrugation cladding to the outside and finish that up by painting it we're
about to go to the table to see the final product but real quick some
